commander.name: Gustav von Vaerst
commander.notes: Wounded at Battle of Gazala, May 28, 1942. Replaced temporarily by Eduard Crasemann until August 1942.

details.notes: Tank strength as of June 1, 1942. Includes operational and short-term repairable vehicles. Excludes long-term maintenance.

supply_logistics.supply_notes: Extended supply lines from Tripoli (1,600 km) caused chronic fuel shortages. British air and naval interdiction reduced supply convoys. Division frequently operated below optimal fuel reserves.

weather_environment.terrain: Coastal desert, rocky plateau, sand dunes
weather_environment.weather_impact: Extreme heat degraded vehicle performance. Dust storms reduced visibility and clogged air filters. Mirages complicated reconnaissance. Limited water sources dictated operational planning.
weather_environment.seasonal_notes: May-June 1942: Peak heat season. Sandstorms common. No rainfall expected.

operational_status.notes: Status as of June 1, 1942, immediately before capture of Tobruk. Division had sustained moderate casualties at Gazala (May 26-June 14) but remained combat effective.

sources.title: German Order of Battle, February 1942
sources.author: US Army Command and General Staff College
sources.notes: Detailed TO&E from February 1942, extrapolated to June 1942 based on battle reports

sources.title: 15. Panzer-Division operational history
sources.author: Multiple web sources (Feldgrau.com, German Wikipedia)
sources.notes: Commander information, battle participation, equipment types

known_gaps: Exact June 1942 TO&E (using February 1942 baseline with battle adjustments)
Detailed company-level breakdown beyond regimental structure
Individual vehicle serial numbers or unit assignments
Daily fuel consumption rates (estimated from operational radius)
Detailed Tessin entry (Band 14 covers 1943 reconstitution, not 1942 North Africa division)
data_quality.validation_notes: Division strength and equipment counts cross-referenced across multiple sources. Commander information confirmed from multiple sources. Supply situation inferred from historical context and operational reports.
